Background.text:
During weeks 6 and 7 of gestation, the GI tract becomes occluded then recanalizes during weeks 8 to 10
Duodenal atresia is thought to result from failure of recanalization
Often associated with other malformations such as
biliary atresia
or gallbladder agenesis
May also be associated with cardiac, renal, or vertebral abnormalities
About a quarter of patients born with duodenal atresia have
Down syndrome

Clinical_Features.text:
Presentation is very early in the postnatal period
Abdominal distention and bilious
emesis
within first 24 hours of birth
Abdomen often markedly distended, with visible or palpable loops of bowel
NG tube
aspirate >20 mL
Signs of
dehydration
(e.g. dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, and sunken fontanelle)
+/- Signs of other congenital anomalies

Differential_Diagnosis.text:
Malrotation with
volvulus
Hirschsprung's disease
Meconium
ileus
Other intestinal atresia

tables.': Esophageal stenosis/atresiaPyloric stenosisIntestinal stenosis/atresiaDuodenal atresiaMalrotation Â±volvulusIncarceratedherniaMeconium ileus/plugHirschsprung's diseaseImperforate anusEnteric duplications
Inborn errors of metabolismAdrenal insufficiencyCongenital adrenal hyperplasia

Evaluation.text:
Imaging
AP, lateral, and cross table
XR
should be obtained on all infants with concern for obstruction
Classic double bubble sign due to dilation of the stomach and proximal duodenum
Absent distal gas

Management.text:
NPO
NG tube
to suction
Correct
fluid
and
electrolyte abnormalities
Ampicillin
and
gentamicin
(to prevent post-op infection)
Surgery
